page.title: 03QUAKER HOUSE * HEDGERLEY
page.content: Quaker House was three old cottages built in the Tudor Period. A Quaker bought it, did it up and sold it again in 1957. It was called the Quaker House because Quakers used to have meetings there which started in 1662. It had a central fire and there was a smoke hole in the ceiling because chimneys did not exist then. It was a prosperous farmhouse. The top floor of the house was used for sleeping and storage. The first occupants were sheep owners, it was the Elizabethan Period and wool was needed. Later, when the chimney was installed it was put in the wall of two rooms so they could both be heated. There is no true documentry evidence of the house. In 1656 a man wrote the history of the Quakers.
